title: Shortened scan time due to software glitch in specific scan sequence.
description:
Imaging Software existing version installed: v1.0.89 Release 9

Imaging Software General Availability version: v1.1.24 Release 3

Latest General Availability Release Candidate is available, please contact OEM / Service Integrator to update the software. Alternatively, you may Re-run the sequence by following below steps

General Steps for Re-Running a Sequence on Siemens Magnetom 1.5 tesla:

  • Patient Positioning and Preparation: Ensure the patient is properly re-positioned in the scanner if they were removed after the initial incomplete scan. Repeat any necessary pre-scan calibrations.
  • Access Exam List: Locate the patient's exam on the scanner console. This might involve navigating to a list of recent exams or searching by patient ID.
  • Identify Incomplete Sequence: Within the exam list, find the specific sequence that encountered the error (error code 111 in this case). The user interface might indicate incomplete or interrupted sequences.
  • Re-run Option: You might see a dedicated "Re-run" or "Repeat" button associated with the specific sequence. Alternatively, there might be an option to resume the scan from the point of interruption.
  • Confirmation and Scan Start: Confirm all scan parameters are as intended and initiate the re-run of the chosen sequence.

title: System temperature exceeding safe limit during high-power sequence.
description:
Current Chiller Water Inlet and Outlet to MRI Cooling System:

Inlet Water Temperature to MRI cooling system: 12°C

Outlet Water Temperature to MRI cooling system: 16°C

IAQ (Indoor Air Quality Performance):

MRI Room Set Temperature: 20°C

MRI Room allowed temperature: 20°C - 22°C

MRI Room Current Temperature: 24°C

While the chiller seems to be working effectively with inlet and outlet temperature as 12°C and 16°C respectively, it is suggested to monitor the MRI system's internal temperatures during future scans, particularly during high-power sequences. This will help identify if specific components within the MRI are generating excessive heat. Since the issue likely lies with the MRI itself and not the chiller, here are some actions you can take to address Error 007 (system temperature exceeding safe limit):

  • Cooling System Check: Inspect the MRI's internal cooling system for functionality issues like clogged passages, malfunctioning fans, or low coolant levels.
  • Sequence Optimization: Check if alternative scan sequences can achieve similar diagnostic goals with lower power requirements.
  • Room Temperature Control: MRI machine room temperature is way beyond the allowed temperature and setpoint. Ensure the MRI room is cool and well-ventilated to prevent additional heat buildup around the scanner.
  • Scan Shortening: If feasible with the diagnostic goals, explore ways to shorten the specific high-power sequence that triggered the error.

Note: The above software version and steps to re-run sequence are indicative and for demo purposes only.

title: Excessive drift in magnet subsystem.
description:
MRI Data: SNR (dB) snr_data; is a bit low for scan_type scan but might be sufficient depending on the specific sequence. A low SNR can be a contributing factor to needing a longer scan time to acquire enough signal, but it's unlikely to directly cause magnet drift.

Drift (Hz/ppm): The high values (Drift in drift_hz Hz and drift_ppm ppm) indicate significant drift in the magnet field, which is the root cause of error 102.

Other Values: Scan time, grad performance, coil type, temperatures, RF power, gradient current, and patient position seem normal.

Error 102 is a serious concern and indicates a potential issue with the MRI's magnet. Here's what you should do:

  • MRI Shutdown and Service: Do not attempt to run further scans. Shut down the MRI system and contact the MRI OEM / Service integrator department immediately. This is a critical hardware issue that requires qualified service personnel to diagnose and fix the magnet subsystem drift.
  • Data Backup (if possible): If feasible and the system allows, attempt to back up any acquired data before a complete shutdown. However, prioritize the safety of the equipment and personnel over data retrieval.
  • Service Engineer Visit: A qualified service engineer needs to visit the site to diagnose the cause of the magnet drift. This might involve running diagnostic tests and potentially replacing faulty components within the magnet subsystem.
  • Safety Checks: After repairs, the service engineer will perform comprehensive safety checks to ensure the magnet operates within safe parameters before resuming operation.

Important Note: Do not attempt to operate the MRI scanner until a qualified service engineer diagnoses and repairs the magnet subsystem drift. Running the scanner in this state can lead to further damage and potential safety hazards.

title: Low signal-to-noise ratio in cardiac images likely due to malfunctioning coil element.
description:
The provided data indicates an MRI angiography scan_type scan with an error code of 201, signifying a low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Let's dissect the data:

SNR (dB): snr_data dB is on the lower end for an angiography scan_type scan. A low SNR can lead to grainy images and difficulty in visualizing details.

Drift (Hz/ppm): The values (drift_hz Hz and drift_ppm ppm) seem acceptable, indicating no significant magnet drift.

Other Values: Scan time, gradient performance, coil type (scan_type Coil is appropriate), temperatures, RF power, gradient current, and patient position appear normal.

Recommendations to Avoid Reoccurrence:

  • Coil Check: Ensure the coil_type is properly connected and positioned. A loose connection or misplacement can affect signal reception.
  • Sequence Optimization: Explore alternative angiography scan_type sequences that might achieve better SNR with the existing hardware.
  • Averaging Techniques: Discuss the possibility of using signal averaging techniques during the scan. By acquiring and averaging multiple data sets, SNR can be improved. This might come at the cost of longer scan times.
  • Contrast Agent: Depending on the specific angiography scan_type procedure, consider if administering a contrast agent could enhance the signal within the blood vessels, improving image quality.
  • Hardware Check (if necessary): If the above steps don't resolve the issue consistently, consult the OEM/ Service Integrator department to check for potential hardware problems within the coil or RF system that might be contributing to the low SNR.

By implementing these recommendations, you can increase the likelihood of acquiring high-quality angiogram images with improved signal-to-noise ratio in future scans.

title: Image quality degradation due to excessive patient motion.
description:
Error: 809:

The provided data indicates an MRI scan of the wrist with the following observations:

  • Scan Type: scan_type
  • Image Quality: Error 809 suggests image quality degradation due to excessive patient motion.
  • Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR): snr_data dB (considered good)
  • Slice Thickness: slice_thickness mm
  • Frequency Drift:  drift_hz and drift_ppm ppm (might be within acceptable limits depending on the specific scanner)
  • Gradient Performance: grad_perf G/cm/ms (within normal range)
  • Coil Type: coil_type
  • System Temperature: sys_temp °C (within normal range)
  • Cryo Boiloff: cyro_boiloff liters/hour (likely within normal range)

Actions to Avoid Breakdown

While the data doesn't show any immediate risk of breakdown, the motion artifact necessitates corrective actions to improve future image quality.

  • Patient Motion Correction Techniques: Implement strategies to minimize patient motion during the scan. This could involve better communication, sedation for anxious patients, or specialized equipment for immobilization.

Motion Correction Steps During Image Reconstruction

Even with motion correction techniques, some artifacts might arise. Here are image reconstruction techniques to address them:

  1. Prospective Motion Correction: Continuously monitors patient motion and adjusts the scan sequence in real-time to minimize artifacts.
  2. Retrospective Motion Correction: Corrects for motion artifacts after data acquisition using techniques like:
    • Real-time phase updating
    • Slice-to-volume correction
    • Elastic registration
  3. Navigator Correction: Utilizes real-time navigator signals to track patient motion and correct for it during the scan.

By implementing these steps, you can significantly reduce the impact of patient motion and MRI Scan Data Analysis

title: Injector malfunction - contrast not administered properly.
description:
Error: 402:

The provided MRI scan data indicates an error (code 402) related to injector malfunction, which means the contrast agent was not administered properly during the scan.

Here are the observations and actions required:

Observations:

  • Error 402: Injector malfunction - contrast not administered properly

Actions required:

  • Actions to administer contrast:
    1. Check the injector pump and tubing for leaks or blockages.
    2. Verify the contrast media is prepared correctly and within expiration.
    3. Ensure proper injection protocol is followed for the specific contrast and patient.
    4. Re-run the scan after resolving the injector issue.

By following these steps, you can ensure proper contrast administration for future MRI scans and avoid encountering this error again.

title: Flow artifact during angiography sequence obscuring blood vessels.
description:
Error 707:

Analysis of MRI Scan Data and Observations

The provided data snippet shows information from a single MRI scan of the foot. Here's what we can observe:

  • Scan Type:  scan_type
  • Scan Time:  scan_time seconds (scan_time_minutes minutes)
  • SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio):  snr_data dB (good signal)
  • Slice Thickness:  slice_thickness mm (high resolution)
  • Drift:  drift_hz (minimal)
  • Drift (ppm):  drift_ppm ppm (acceptable)
  • Gradient Performance:  grad_perf G/cm/ms (within normal range)
  • Coil Type:  coil_type  (appropriate for the scan)
  • Error Code: 707 - Flow artifact during angiography sequence

Observations and Actions to Avoid Breakdown

Based on the data and error code, there's no imminent risk of breakdown. However, the error code indicates an issue with the scan itself:

  • Flow Artifact: This means blood flow in the foot is causing blurring or distortion in the image, obscuring blood vessels during the angiography sequence.

Addressing Flow Artifact (Error 707)

Here's how to potentially reduce flow artifact and improve the angiography sequence:

  1. Adjust Velocity Encoding (VENC):
    • VENC determines the maximum blood flow velocity the scan can measure. If set too low, fast-flowing blood creates artifacts.
    • Increase VENC value in subsequent scans to accommodate faster blood flow.
  2. Consider Phase Contrast Imaging (PCI):
    • PCI is another technique for visualizing blood flow, less susceptible to flow artifacts compared to traditional angiography sequences.
    • If VENC adjustments don't resolve the issue, consider using PCI for future foot angiography scans.
  3. Reduce Flip Angle:
    • A high flip angle can exacerbate flow artifacts.
    • Experiment with slightly lower flip angles while maintaining sufficient signal-to-noise ratio (SNR).

Important Note: These are general recommendations. Optimal settings depend on the specific MRI scanner model, patient factors, and desired image quality. Always consult the MRI system's user manual and a qualified medical professional for specific adjustments and protocols.

title: Motion artifact due to patient breathing during long scan.
description:
Error: 501

Analysis of MRI Scan Data and Observations:

Scan Details:

  • Scan Type:  scan_type
  • Scan Time:  scan_time seconds (scan_time_minutes minutes)
  • SNR (Signal-to-Noise Ratio):  snr_data dB (good)
  • Slice Thickness:  slice_thickness mm (standard)
  • Drift (frequency): drift_hz Hz (minimal)
  • Drift (ppm): drift_ppm ppm (acceptable)
  • Gradient Performance: grad_perf G/cm/ms (within normal range)
  • Coil Type: coil_type (appropriate)
  • Error Code: 501 - Motion Artifact due to patient breathing

Observations:

  • The scan appears to have been completed successfully despite the motion artifact.
  • SNR is good, indicating a clear image.
  • Other technical aspects (drift, gradient performance) seem to be within normal ranges.
  • The scan time (12.5 minutes) is relatively long for a wrist scan, potentially contributing to the breathing motion artifact.

Actions to Avoid Breakdown and Improve Scan Quality:

  1. Reduce Scan Time:
    • Explore options for shorter scan sequences specifically designed for wrist imaging while maintaining diagnostic quality.
  2. Patient Preparation and Coaching:
    • Instruct the patient on breathing techniques to minimize motion during the scan.
    • Practice relaxation techniques beforehand, especially if the patient experiences anxiety.
    • Consider using a respiratory belt to monitor breathing patterns and potentially trigger image acquisition during breath-hold periods.
  3. Image Reconstruction Techniques:
    • Utilize advanced image reconstruction algorithms specifically designed to reduce motion artifact. These algorithms can potentially salvage data affected by slight patient movement.
  4. Communication and Feedback:
    • Communicate the importance of staying still during the scan to the patient.
    • Provide clear instructions and answer any questions they may have beforehand.
    • Consider offering positive reinforcement during the scan to encourage cooperation.

title: RF transmission error - signal not reaching tissues properly
description:
Error: 601

Analysis of MRI Scan Data and Observations

The provided data snippet shows information from a single MRI scan. Here's an analysis of the KPIs (Key Performance Indicators) and observations:

  • Scan Type: scan_type
  • Scan Time: scan_time seconds (almost scan_time_minutes minutes)
  • SNR (dB): snr_data dB (good signal-to-noise ratio)
  • Slice Thickness: slice_thickness mm (standard thickness)
  • Drift (Hz): drift_hz Hz (acceptable range)
  • Drift (ppm): drift_ppm ppm (acceptable range)
  • Grad Perf (G/cm/ms): grad_perf (within normal range)
  • Coil Type: coil_type (matches the scan type)
  • Error Code: 603 (RF transmission error)
  • System Temperature: sys_temp °C (within normal range)
  • Cryo Boiloff: cyro_boiloff liters/hour (normal range)

Observations:

  • The scan seems to have completed successfully despite the error code.
  • SNR is good, indicating a clear image.
  • Other parameters are within normal ranges.
  • However, the presence of Error 603 (RF transmission error) signifies a problem with the Radio Frequency (RF) system.

Actions to Avoid Breakdown

  • Investigate Error 603: This error indicates the RF signal isn't reaching the tissues properly. A breakdown could occur if left unaddressed.
  • Calibrate the RF System: Recalibrating the RF system ensures proper signal transmission and image quality.

Step-by-Step Instructions for RF System Calibration (General Guidelines)

Note: The exact calibration procedure may vary depending on the specific MRI machine model. Refer to the manufacturer's instructions for detailed steps. Here's a general outline:

  1. Preparation:
    • Power down the MRI system and secure the area.
    • Prepare calibration phantoms (objects that mimic human tissues) as specified by the manufacturer.
  2. System Checks:
    • Perform basic system checks like cooling system functionality and cable connections.
  3. RF Coil Calibration:
    • Mount the appropriate calibration phantom for the Pelvis coil.
    • Run automated RF coil calibration routines provided by the manufacturer's software. These routines typically involve sending test pulses and measuring the response.
  4. B1+ Field Mapping:
    • This step ensures the RF field is uniform across the scanned volume.
    • The system will acquire data using phantoms or the patient (with informed consent).
    • Software will analyze the data and adjust the RF pulse parameters for optimal field uniformity.
  5. SAR (Specific Absorption Rate) Calibration:
    • This ensures safe operation by measuring and limiting the amount of energy absorbed by tissues during the scan.
    • Use phantoms to calibrate SAR for different coil configurations and pulse sequences.
  6. Validation:
    • Run test scans after calibration to confirm proper signal transmission and image quality.
  7. Documentation:
    • Record the calibration results and date for future reference.

title: Reduced gradient current during rapid angiography sequence might indicate.
description:
Error: 304

Observations from the MRI Scan Data:

  • Scan Type: scan_type
  • Scan Time: scan_time seconds (around scan_time_minutes minutes)
  • Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR): snr_data dB (good)
  • Slice Thickness: slice_thickness mm (standard)
  • Frequency Drift: drift_hz Hz, drift_ppm ppm (slightly higher than usual)
  • Gradient Performance: grad_perf G/cm/ms (within normal range)
  • Coil Type: coil_type
  • Error Code: 304 - Reduced gradient current during rapid angiography sequence

Analysis of Error Code 304:

The error code indicates a problem with the gradient system during a rapid angiography sequence. This suggests that the gradient coils, which are responsible for creating the magnetic field variations needed for image formation, are not receiving enough current. This can lead to artifacts and distortions in the final image.

Actions to Avoid Breakdown:

  1. Investigate Gradient Coil Issues:
    • Check for any loose connections or hardware problems with the gradient system.
    • Ensure proper cooling for the gradient coils to prevent overheating.
  2. Perform Gradient Coil Tuning:
    • This process optimizes the performance of the gradient coils for maximum efficiency and minimizes current requirements.
    • A qualified engineer should perform this using specialized software and hardware.
  3. Optimize Shim Settings:
    • Shimming corrects for magnetic field inhomogeneities within the scanner.
    • Improper shimming can contribute to increased current draw on the gradients.
    • A qualified engineer should perform this optimization alongside gradient tuning.
  4. Review Angiography Sequence:
    • Analyze if the specific angiography sequence used is particularly demanding on the gradient system.
    • If possible, consider alternative sequences that require less current.
  5. Monitor Drift and System Temperature:
    • Keep an eye on frequency drift and system temperature as these can be early indicators of gradient coil problems.
    • Regularly scheduled preventative maintenance can help identify potential issues before they cause a breakdown.
  • Shim Selection: Choose an appropriate coil shim based on the anatomy being scanned (e.g., head coil, knee coil).
  • Pulse Sequence Selection: Select a specific pulse sequence for tuning, often provided by the scanner software. Common choices include gradient echo (GRE) sequences.
  • Parameter Adjustments: The software will guide adjustments to various parameters to optimize the signal. Here's a general idea:
  • Gradient Strength: This is adjusted to achieve a desired level of signal intensity within safe operating limits for the scanner and patient (if applicable).
  • Linearity: Adjustments are made to minimize signal distortions caused by imperfections in the magnetic field generated by the gradient coils.
  • Centering: The position of the gradient field is optimized to ensure the desired region of interest is being imaged accurately.
  • Monitoring and Optimization: The system will display results like signal intensity and field homogeneity. Iterative adjustments are made until optimal criteria are met as defined by the chosen pulse sequence.
  • Saving and Verification: Once satisfied with the tuning, save the parameters for future use with similar coils and scan protocols. Perform verifications using phantoms (test objects) to confirm image quality.
